sn1.81:1.1.eng: “Who in the world is free of strife?

sn1.81:1.4.eng: Who always lives as their own master?

sn1.81:2.1.eng: To whom do mother, father, and brothers

sn1.81:2.4.eng: is bowed to even by aristocrats?”

sn1.81:3.1.eng: “Ascetics are free of strife in the world.
sn1.81:3.1.comm: How this is achieved is treated in MN 139:0.2.

sn1.81:3.2.eng: The life of ascetics is not wasted.
sn1.81:3.2.comm: The word for “life” here (vusitaṁ) commonly describes the completion of the spiritual path.

sn1.81:3.4.eng: Ascetics always live as their own master.

sn1.81:4.2.eng: bow to ascetics when they’re established.

sn1.81:4.3.eng: Even though an ascetic is low born,

sn1.81:4.4.eng: they’re bowed to even by aristocrats.”

sn1.81:5.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on Deities are complete.

sn1.9:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho sā devatā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn1.9:1.2.eng: Standing to one side, that deity spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn1.9:2.1.eng: “One fond of conceit can’t be tamed,

sn1.9:2.3.eng: Living negligent alone in the wilderness,

sn1.9:2.4.eng: they can’t cross beyond Death’s dominion.”

sn1.9:3.1.eng: “Having given up conceit, serene within oneself,

sn1.9:3.2.eng: with a good heart, everywhere free;

sn1.9:3.3.eng: living diligent alone in the wilderness,

sn10.1:1.1.comm: The yakkha Indaka asks how the body can grow in the womb, apparently because he believes in an immortal, immaterial soul. | Compare Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.8: “When at birth this person takes on a body, he becomes united with bad things, and when at death he leaves it behind, he gets rid of those bad things” (Olivelle’s translation). This shares many terms with Indaka’s verse: use of ayaṁ for the subject; sarīra for the body; sajjati for saṁsṛjyate. Furthermore, the “bad things” are explained in the commentary as the body and organs with which the soul becomes burdened at birth. This passage is part of the dialogue on the “light of a person” between Yājñavalkya and Janaka, which is alluded to several times in the Pali Suttas.

sn10.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati indakūṭe pabbate, indakassa yakkhassa bhavane.
sn10.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha on Mount Indra’s Peak, the haunt of the native spirit Indaka.
sn10.1:1.2.comm: Indaka is named after the mountain he inhabits. The mountain itself might the same as Mount Vediyaka, where Sakka/Indra appeared to the Buddha at Indra’s hill cave (DN 21:1.1.2). Indaka’s interest in human fertility is professional: such yakkhas were fertility deities, called upon with sacrifice in times of birth and death of children. | The first two suttas of this discourse feature otherwise unknown yakkhas named Indaka and Sakka, while the Sakka/Indra is sometimes referred to as yakkha (MN 37:5.3).

sn10.1:1.3.pli: Atha kho indako yakkho yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn10.1:1.3.eng: Then the native spirit Indaka went up to the Buddha, and addressed him in verse:

sn10.1:2.1.eng: “The Buddhas say that form is not the soul.
sn10.1:2.1.comm: While this exact wording (rūpaṁ na jīvan) doesn’t seem to be a direct quote of the Buddha, it is a similar to taṁ jīvaṁ taṁ sarīraṁ, which the Buddha did indeed deny. Taken by itself, this does not deny that there is a soul, only that it is not physical. The use of jīva for soul, rather than attā, is characteristic of the Jains, but is used by Vedists as well.

sn10.1:2.2.eng: Then how does this one obtain this body?
sn10.1:2.2.comm: Indaka uses the Upaniṣadic style, indicating a subject with ayaṁ (“this one”) which is assumed to be the immortal Self or Person. Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.8 has sa vā ayaṁ puruṣo, referring back the previous sentence, “this person made of consciousness amid the organs, the light in the heart” (ayaṃ vijñānamayaḥ prāṇeṣu hṛdyantarjyotiḥ puruṣaḥ).

sn10.1:2.3.eng: From where do his bones and organs come?
sn10.1:2.3.comm: Yaka is normally “liver”, but the commentary explains yakapiṇḍa here as the “900 lumps of flesh”, i.e. “organs”.

sn10.1:2.4.eng: How does this one coalesce in the womb?”
sn10.1:2.4.comm: Bodhi (Connected Discourses, note 559) proposes deriving sajjati from sṛj, which he renders “begotten”. This is born out by the Upaniṣad’s saṁsṛjyate, which has the senses of being “created” and being “joined”.

sn10.1:3.1.comm: “Zygote” is kalala, a newly fertilized ovum. Commentary: “no more than a drop of cream of ghee on a single fibre of lamb’s wool”.

sn10.1:3.2.comm: Abbuda is otherwise used of a tumor or cancer. This fits the “blastocyst”, which is implanted in the uterine wall about a week after conception. At this time, the commentary says the embryo is the color of meat-washing water. For other meanings, see notes on SN 1.77:1.4 and Snp 3.10:8.2.

sn10.1:3.3.comm: “Gastrula” renders pesi, literally “scrap of flesh”, described as looking like melted lead. The embryo in the third week, only a few millimeters long, is forming distinct layers and emerging from the uterine wall.

sn10.1:3.4.comm: The “embryonic mass” (ghana, literally “clump”) sees the formation of internal organs starting around the fourth week. As the limbs have not yet appeared, the commentary says it is shaped like a chicken egg.

sn10.1:3.5.eng: From that the limb buds appear,
sn10.1:3.5.comm: The commentary locates this in the fifth week, with limbs appearing first like five “pimples”. The medical term is “limb buds”, which become prominent at this time.

sn10.1:3.6.eng: the head hair, body hair, and nails.
sn10.1:3.6.comm: The commentary says the explanation is abridged after the first six or seven weeks. The head hair etc. appear at the time the fetus is mature, namely after 42 weeks (or ten months). Medically, nails and hair are mostly developed by about week 36, which is also the earliest time when a baby is mature, as it may be born with a reasonable chance of survival.

sn10.1:4.2.eng: the food and drink that she consumes—

sn10.1:4.4.eng: the person in the mother’s womb.”
sn10.1:4.4.comm: Whereas Indaka spoke of the subject who obtains a body, the Buddha’s reply avoids any mention of a subject until this last line. The “person” (nara) only appears when the fetus is mature enough to have limbs, hair, and nails.

sn10.10:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn10.10:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn10.10:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro upāsako sukkāya bhikkhuniyā bhojanaṃ adāsi.
sn10.10:1.2.eng: Now at that time a certain lay follower gave food to the nun Sukkā.
sn10.10:1.2.comm: As a donor once remarked, “It’s difficult for women to get material support” (Bu Pd 1:1.23). Passages like this serve to elevate nuns as worthy recipients of donations.

sn10.10:1.3.pli: Atha kho sukkāya bhikkhuniyā abhippasanno yakkho rājagahe rathikāya rathikaṃ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṃ upasaṅkamitvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn10.10:1.3.eng: Then a native spirit was so devoted to Sukkā that he went from street to street and from square to square, and on that occasion recited these verses:

sn10.10:2.1.eng: “O! He has made so much merit!

sn10.10:2.2.eng: That lay follower is so very wise.

sn10.10:2.3.eng: He just gave food to Sukkā,

sn10.10:2.4.eng: who is released from all ties.”

sn10.11:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn10.11:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn10.11:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro upāsako cīrāya bhikkhuniyā cīvaraṃ adāsi.
sn10.11:1.3.eng: Now at that time a certain lay follower gave a robe to the nun Cīrā.

sn10.11:1.4.pli: Atha kho cīrāya bhikkhuniyā abhippasanno yakkho rājagahe rathikāya rathikaṃ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṃ upasaṅkamitvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn10.11:1.4.eng: Then a native spirit was so devoted to Cīrā that he went from street to street and from square to square, and on that occasion recited these verses:

sn10.11:2.1.eng: “O! He has made so much merit!

sn10.11:2.2.eng: That lay-follower is so very wise.

sn10.11:2.3.eng: He gave a robe to Cīrā,

sn10.11:2.4.eng: who is released from all yokes.”

sn10.12:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā āḷaviyaṃ viharati āḷavakassa yakkhassa bhavane.
sn10.12:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Āḷavī in the haunt of the native spirit Āḷavaka.
sn10.12:1.2.comm: Another spirit of place, Āḷavaka’s story (also at Snp 1.10) is perhaps the most beloved of all the yakkha conversions. He is provided with an extensive backstory in the Pali commentaries, and another quite different story in a Chinese Dharmapada (T 211, pp. 575–609). | Āḷavī was a town between Sāvatthī and Rājagaha.

sn10.12:1.3.pli: Atha kho āḷavako yakkho yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn10.12:1.3.eng: Then the native spirit Āḷavaka went up to the Buddha, and said to him:

sn10.12:1.5.eng: Saying, “All right, good sir,” the Buddha went out.

sn10.12:1.7.eng: Saying, “All right, good sir,” the Buddha went in.

sn10.12:1.8.pli: Dutiyampi kho āḷavako yakkho bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn10.12:1.8.eng: And for a second time the native spirit Āḷavaka said to the Buddha,

sn10.12:1.10.eng: Saying, “All right, good sir,” the Buddha went out.

sn10.12:1.12.eng: Saying, “All right, good sir,” the Buddha went in.

sn10.12:1.13.pli: Tatiyampi kho āḷavako yakkho bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn10.12:1.13.eng: And for a third time the native spirit Āḷavaka said to the Buddha,

sn10.12:1.15.eng: Saying, “All right, good sir,” the Buddha went out.

sn10.12:1.17.eng: Saying, “All right, good sir,” the Buddha went in.

sn10.12:1.18.pli: Catutthampi kho āḷavako yakkho bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn10.12:1.18.eng: And for a fourth time the native spirit Āḷavaka said to the Buddha,

sn10.12:1.20.eng: “No, good sir, I won’t get out.

sn10.12:1.22.eng: “I will ask you a question, ascetic.

sn10.12:1.23.pli: Sace me na byākarissasi, cittaṃ vā te khipissāmi, hadayaṃ vā te phālessāmi, pādesu vā gahetvā pāragaṅgāya khipissāmī”ti.
sn10.12:1.23.eng: If you don’t answer me, I’ll drive you insane, or explode your heart, or grab you by the feet and throw you to the far shore of the Ganges!”

sn10.12:1.24.pli: “Na khvāhaṃ taṃ, āvuso, passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya, yo me cittaṃ vā khipeyya hadayaṃ vā phāleyya, pādesu vā gahetvā pāragaṅgāya khipeyya.
sn10.12:1.24.eng: “I don’t see anyone in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans who could do that to me.

sn10.12:1.25.pli: Api ca tvaṃ, āvuso, puccha yadā kaṅkhasī”ti (…).
sn10.12:1.25.eng: But anyway, ask what you wish.”

sn10.12:2.2.eng: What brings happiness when practiced well?

sn10.12:2.3.eng: What’s the sweetest taste of all?

sn10.12:2.4.eng: The one they say has the best life: how do they live?”

sn10.12:3.1.eng: “Faith here is a person’s best wealth.

sn10.12:3.2.eng: The teaching brings happiness when practiced well.

sn10.12:3.3.eng: Truth is the sweetest taste of all.

sn10.12:3.4.eng: The one they say has the best life lives by wisdom.”

sn10.12:4.2.eng: How do you cross the deluge?

sn10.12:4.3.eng: How do you get over suffering?

sn10.12:5.3.eng: By energy you get past suffering,

sn10.12:6.3.eng: How do you get a good reputation?

sn10.12:6.4.eng: How do you hold on to friends?

sn10.12:6.5.eng: How do the departed not grieve

sn10.12:6.6.eng: when passing from this world to the next?”

sn10.12:7.2.eng: gains wisdom by wanting to learn,

sn10.12:7.3.eng: having faith in the perfected ones,

sn10.12:7.4.eng: and the teaching for becoming extinguished.

sn10.12:8.2.eng: and working hard you earn wealth.

sn10.12:8.3.eng: Truthfulness wins you a good reputation.

sn10.12:8.4.eng: You hold on to friends by giving.

sn10.12:8.5.eng: That’s how the departed do not grieve

sn10.12:8.6.eng: when passing from this world to the next.

sn10.12:9.2.comm: Following Cone’s Dictionary of Pali, Pali gharamesin probably stands for Sanskrit gṛhamedhin, an “householder of discernment”, a man of mature years who has completed his education.

sn10.12:9.3.eng: does not grieve after passing away:

sn10.12:10.1.eng: Go ahead, ask others as well,

sn10.12:10.2.eng: there are many ascetics and brahmins.

sn10.12:10.3.eng: See whether anything better is found

sn10.12:10.4.eng: than truth, principle, generosity, and patience.”
sn10.12:10.4.comm: Readings are uncertain. Chinese parallels at SA2 325 and SA 1326 support dama or danta here rather than dhamma. DN 30:1.6.2 has both, and elsewhere we find both dhamma and dama commonly used alongside sacca.

sn10.12:11.4.eng: what’s good for the next life.

sn10.12:12.1.eng: It was truly for my benefit

sn10.12:12.2.eng: that the Buddha came to stay at Āḷavī.

sn10.12:12.4.eng: where a gift is very fruitful.

sn10.12:13.2.eng: village to village, town to town,

sn10.12:13.4.eng: and the clear rightness of the teaching!”

sn10.12:14.5.eng: The Linked Discourses with Native Spirits are complete.

sn10.2:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
sn10.2:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

sn10.2:1.2.pli: Atha kho sakkanāmako yakkho yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn10.2:1.2.eng: Then a spirit who was Sakka in name only went up to the Buddha, and addressed him in verse:
sn10.2:1.2.comm: The suffix -nāmaka is a slight. Compare “Senior in name only” (SN 21.10:1.2) and nāmaka in the sense “mere words” (MN 80:15.5, MN 99:10.5). His verse is similar to that of Māra in SN 4.14.

sn10.2:2.3.eng: It’s not a good idea for you, ascetic,

sn10.2:3.2.comm: The Buddha avoids nāmaka and politely calls him “Sakka”.

sn10.2:3.3.eng: it’s unworthy for a wise person

sn10.2:3.4.eng: not to think of the other with sympathy.
sn10.2:3.4.comm: Accepting the variant ananukampituṁ at Ne 37:194.4, which is endorsed by that text’s commentaries. The text as stands enjoins lack of compassion, which cannot be right.

sn10.2:4.2.eng: with a mind clear and confident,

sn10.3:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā gayāyaṃ viharati ṭaṅkitamañce sūcilomassa yakkhassa bhavane.
sn10.3:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Gayā on the cut-stone ledge in the haunt of Spiky the native spirit.
sn10.3:1.1.comm: This discourse is also at Snp 2.5.

sn10.3:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kharo ca yakkho sūcilomo ca yakkho bhagavato avidūre atikkamanti.
sn10.3:1.2.eng: Now at that time the native spirits Shaggy and Spiky were passing by not far from the Buddha.
sn10.3:1.2.comm: “Shaggy” is khara and “Spiky” is sūciloma, literally “needle-hair”. Some yakkhas are magnificent kings or warriors, but this pair are more like grotesque demons (rakkhasas), a stereotype that bedeviled yakṣas of later times. Khara is found for a number of demons in Sanskrit. We don’t find suciloma, but compare the demons Khara and his twin sister, the ugly and mutilated Śūrpaṇakhā (“wicker-nails”).

sn10.3:1.3.pli: Atha kho kharo yakkho sūcilomaṃ yakkhaṃ etadavoca:

sn10.3:1.6.pli: Yāva jānāmi yadi vā so samaṇo yadi vā pana so samaṇako”ti.
sn10.3:1.6.eng: I’ll soon find out whether he’s an ascetic or a faker.”

sn10.3:2.1.pli: Atha kho sūcilomo yakkho yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato kāyaṃ upanāmesi.
sn10.3:2.1.eng: Then Spiky went up to the Buddha and leaned up against his body,

sn10.3:2.3.pli: Atha kho sūcilomo yakkho bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn10.3:2.3.eng: Then Spiky said to the Buddha,

sn10.3:2.7.eng: “I will ask you a question, ascetic.

sn10.3:2.8.pli: Sace me na byākarissasi, cittaṃ vā te khipissāmi, hadayaṃ vā te phālessāmi, pādesu vā gahetvā pāragaṅgāya khipissāmī”ti.
sn10.3:2.8.eng: If you don’t answer me, I’ll drive you insane, or explode your heart, or grab you by the feet and throw you to the far shore of the Ganges!”
sn10.3:2.8.comm: Considering the Ganges is 100 km away, this is even more impressive.

sn10.3:2.9.pli: “Na khvāhaṃ taṃ, āvuso, passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya, yo me cittaṃ vā khipeyya hadayaṃ vā phāleyya pādesu vā gahetvā pāragaṅgāya khipeyya;
sn10.3:2.9.eng: “I don’t see anyone in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans who could do that to me.

sn10.3:2.10.pli: api ca tvaṃ, āvuso, puccha yadā kaṅkhasī”ti. (…)
sn10.3:2.10.eng: But anyway, ask what you wish.”

sn10.3:3.1.eng: “Where do greed and hate come from?
sn10.3:3.1.comm: Despite their savage demeanor, they pivot right away to deep Dhamma questions. This kind of rapid pivot is characteristic of such conversion narratives.

sn10.3:3.2.eng: From where spring discontent, desire, and terror?

sn10.3:3.3.eng: Where do the mind’s thoughts originate,

sn10.3:3.4.eng: like a crow let loose by boys.”

sn10.3:4.2.eng: from here spring discontent, desire, and terror;

sn10.3:4.3.eng: here’s where the mind’s thoughts originate,

sn10.3:4.4.eng: like a crow let loose by boys.

sn10.3:5.1.eng: Born of affection, originating in oneself,

sn10.3:5.2.eng: like prop roots sprouting from a banyan;
sn10.3:5.2.comm: The banyan is “trunk-born” (khandhaja) in two ways. As an epiphyte, it is sometimes called the “strangler fig”, since it grows around the trunk of a previous tree, strangling it (much like the māluva below). Then the banyan sends out aerial roots from the branches; when they reach the ground they establish themselves as supportive trunks known as “prop roots”, so that even if original trunk dies, the tree survives. Thus the tree itself is “trunk-born” and its multiple prop roots are also “trunk-born”. Grammar and commentary indicate the second sense is meant here. The metaphor is even more apt, since the word nigrodha (“banyan”) means “down-grower”, as the tree grows not to the sky but back into the earth.

sn10.3:5.3.eng: the many kinds of attachment to sensual pleasures

sn10.3:5.4.eng: are like camel’s foot creeper <j>creeping through the woods.
sn10.3:5.4.comm: The “camel’s foot creeper” (māluva) takes root and grows over the tree, ultimately engulfing and destroying it (MN 45:4.1).

sn10.3:6.1.eng: Those who understand where they come from

sn10.3:6.2.eng: get rid of them—listen up, spirit!

sn10.3:6.3.eng: They cross this flood so hard to cross,

sn10.3:6.4.eng: not crossed before, so as to not be reborn.”

sn10.4:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā magadhesu viharati maṇimālike cetiye maṇibhaddassa yakkhassa bhavane.
sn10.4:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans at the Maṇimālika Shrine, the haunt of the native spirit Maṇibhadda.

sn10.4:1.2.pli: Atha kho maṇibhaddo yakkho yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn10.4:1.2.eng: Then the native spirit Maṇibhadda went up to the Buddha, and spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:
sn10.4:1.2.comm: Maṇibhadda means “auspicious jewel”. Yakkhas of this name are found in both Brahmanism and Jainism as bestowers of wealth. Hindu texts identify him as brother of Kuvera, king of yakkhas, and tutellary deity of merchants and travellers. Mahāvīra was once said to have stayed at a Maṇibhadra shrine, but that was in Mithila, north of the Ganges.

sn10.4:2.1.comm: Maṇibhadda plays on his own name, taking mindfulness to be auspicious, rather than jewels.

sn10.4:2.3.eng: Each new day is better for the mindful,

sn10.4:2.4.eng: and they are freed from enmity.”

sn10.4:3.3.eng: Each new day is better for the mindful,

sn10.4:3.4.eng: but they’re not freed from enmity.

sn10.4:4.1.eng: But someone whose mind delights in harmlessness,
sn10.4:4.1.comm: The Buddha does not advocate mindfulness as the sole solution for all difficulties. Rather, specific problems require relevant antidotes, though of course mindfulness is always present.

sn10.4:4.3.eng: with love for all living creatures—

sn10.4:4.4.eng: they have no enmity for anyone.”
